dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is almost up. Smog clearing. A small PRIVATE PLAN comes in for a landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plane touches down, we see A BLACK SUV, A THUG on MOTORCYCLE (we'll call him PONCH), and two other men awaiting. As the three men on the ground look on, the plane taxis t stop, kills its engine. Silence, then -- We hear SOMETHING - is that MUSIC? Ever so faint. It soun a little like Pantera’s “Cowboys from Hell.” The bodyguar turn to see -- Across the airfield, in the distance - TAYLOR'S CAR. Screaming towards them. And we can really start to hear i now, the PANTERA. We stay behind THE BODYGUARDS as they raise SCOPED ASSAUL RIFLES; shoulder them. The car shrieks closer. The bodyguards take AIM and FIRE off a volley of shots. BLAM. BLAM. BLAM. BLAM. BLAM. The CAR gets HIT! It flips over several times, lands on i side in the dirt, a couple hundred yards away. The bodyguards and Ponch look to each other, as, BEHIND

dialogues.speaker: THEM --
dialogues.text: A bodyguard emerges from the plane, holds the door open for...CRISTOBAL SIFUENTES. He looks intimidating, but there's something about his demeanor that's a little Zen.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: That was a rough one. I hate these little planes. Guys! You're not gonna believe this. The pilot is from the same village as my grandfather in Bolivia - fucking crazy right? Then...he sees the cloud of dust billowing from the crash car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 702 703 704 705 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CRISTOBAL (cont'd) Whoa, what happened? (to bodyguard) I've only been here two minutes and you already shot someone? The bodyguard says something in Spanish. CRISTOBAL (cont'd) A bum rush? (to Ponch) Ver por ellos! Ponch peels off toward the flipped car. And we are -- EXT. AIRFIELD, TAYLOR’S CAR — MOMENTS LATER (D12) 703 Ponch peers into Taylor's wrecked car. In the front seat; two bodies, TAYLOR and VAUGHAN. Dead. The back seat? Empty. Ponch produces a WALKIE, keys it.

dialogues.speaker: PONCH
dialogues.text: Dos Muertos -- He looks at Taylor and Vaughan in bloodied tactical gear. PONCH (cont'd) -- soldados.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Cristobal. One of his goons holds a radio out for Cristobal to listen to.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Soldados? (to bodyguard) Gimme your phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponch circles the car, spots a BLOODY HANDPRINT on the ca That's odd. FOOT TRACKS and fresh blood lead from the backseat, heading AWAY from the flipped car down the runw away from the plane.  BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 3. 706 EXT. PAZAR HOUSE, CABANA — SAME (D12) 706 PAZAR is angrily setting out cups and saucers as NOHO HAN emerges from the garage with a large box.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Okay, Goran, I think this is all of Vacha's things. Maybe we donate these tools to local veterinarian?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: Throw them out. I told him not to go after Barry and he fucking did it anyway. Noho Hank eyes the cups and saucers.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Oh. Are we having guests?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: I'm putting this out for when the fucking cops come to ask me questions.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Should I go get a babka? Two babkas, maybe? His cell phone rings. Pazar looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? Yes, this is he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cristobal holds his cell phone, warmly responds.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Hey, Goran. This is Cristobal Sifuentes, from Bolivia? How are you?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: I am okay. (covers phone) It's Cristobal.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: How is he still alive? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pazar covers BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 4. 707

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: How are you, Cristobal?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Complicated question. See, I flew in because my guys said you took my stash house, and just now two military guys tried to kill me. I hope this aggression is not just about business, because if you wanted in on the stash house, all you had to do was call me. You know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Is he angry?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (covers phone) I can't tell...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: You know, I've been a fan of yours for a while. Like, when you sent me that bullet via DHL, I was like, wow. This guy is next level. Plus we have the same job, you and I. And I know how hard it is to break in in Los Angeles. We should be working together, not against each other. No?

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: (sotto) What's happening? the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (bummed out) He's a super nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: (sotto) That's great.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (covers phone) We fucked up. (into phone) Cristobal, it seems I got bad information. I was told to attack you because you were bloodthirsty maniac. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoever told you that is just wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (covers phone) We need to kill Fuches.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: I mean, you just assumed I was a mean guy without meeting me? Do you know the book The 'Four Agreements'? You owe it to yourself. It's life- changing. Agreement three in the book is "Don't make assumptions."

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (into phone) Don't make assumptions?

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Is that 'The Four Agreements'? Such a great book.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: (into phone) Maybe we could take two steps backwards, start over?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Oh, I wish we could. But you killed a bunch of my guys, so now I gotta kill a bunch of your guys. You know how this shit goes --

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: My family is already quite a bit angry with me for some things that have happened here. And you said men I just sent are dead --

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Barry is dead?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: -- Same military guy you just killed, he killed a few of my guys too, so maybe we are now all even Kevin?

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: If only, man. Agreement number one is "Be impeccable with your word." (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 707 708 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 6.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CRISTOBAL (cont'd) I have to back my people here. So, yeah man, it's a war now.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: War? This is really not good news for me.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: Well, next time you should just reach out. Lesson learned. And if you wishlist 'The Four Agreements' on Amazon, I'll buy it for you. You really never read it?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR
dialogues.text: My wife gave me Mars/Venus book, but I could not get through it.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL
dialogues.text: That's got some good stuff, but it's a little psych one-oh-one for me. Have you read 'The Alchemist'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponch crests a hill at the edge of the airfield, and down into a hollow strewn with junk, wrecked cars, etc. He rides slowly along, keeping an eye out. REVEAL: Behind a junked car, Barry cowers, listening as Ponch rides past. Barry is pretty worse for wear after th SUV flipped. When SUDDENLY --

dialogues.speaker: PONCH, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Quien eres? REVEAL: Ponch stands behind Barry, gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: PONCH
dialogues.text: Quien eres? Por quien trabajas? Barry stares at Ponch, then spots...OVER PONCH'S SHOULDER CHRIS emerges, holding the Bushmaster. He has the drop on Ponch. PONCH (cont'd) Diga me! Quien eres? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 708 709 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 7.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (without looking at him) Chris...

dialogues.speaker: PONCH
dialogues.text: Chingate! Estas muerto. Ponch reaches into his jacket, pulls out his radio.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Chris. He calls his boys we're dead. Chris, Chris...CHRIS! Just as Ponch keys his radio, Chris shoots him. Barry gets up quickly, knowing they need to go. BARRY (cont'd) C'mon. Chris can't stop looking at Ponch's body. BARRY (cont'd) Dude. Let's go. Chris drops the gun -- BARRY (cont'd) No. Pick that up. We'll get rid of it. C'mon! Barry pulls him toward Ponch's nearby motorcycle -- Barry's phone buzzes. A text from Sally: "Where the F are you? Rehearsal's starting!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuches is sitting in the lobby, nursing a coffee, nervous waiting for Barry. He takes a Tums, checks his watch --

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: (to himself) What is going on? He dials his cell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 710 711 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noho Hank is preparing a plate of babka. He answers his phone.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: This is Noho Hank.

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: Hey, bud. Barry hasn't called you to tell you how well the job went, has he? Cuz usually he calls me. And I haven't heard from him. Noho Hank looks around...he shouldn't really be talking t Fuches.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Did Barry do this job with someone else? A military buddy, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Maybe. Why?

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Because if he did...Barry is dead.

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: What...? It lands on Fuches hard.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, it really hasn't hit me yet. Really broken up about it. Big kick in the balls. Fuches drops his cell down on the table, stunned. As he tries to not publicly flip out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss, Loach and several other cops listen to a recording.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh, I wish we could. But you killed a bunch of my guys, so now I gotta kill a bunch of your guys. You know how this shit goes -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My family is already quite a bit angry with me for some things that have happened here. And you said men I just sent are dead...Same military guy you just killed, he killed a few of my guys too, so maybe we are now all even Kevin?

dialogues.speaker: MOSS
dialogues.text: Military...

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If only, man. Agreement number one is "Be impeccable with your word." I have to back my people here. So, yeah man, it's a war now.

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is really not good news for me.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well, next time you should just reach out. Lesson learned. And if you wishlist 'The Four Agreements’ on Amazon, I'll buy it for you. You really never read it?

dialogues.speaker: PAZAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My wife gave me Mars/Venus book, but I could not get through it.

dialogues.speaker: CRISTOBAL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That's got some good stuff, but it's a little psych one-oh-one for me. Have you read 'The Alchemist'? Loach stops the playback.

dialogues.speaker: LOACH
dialogues.text: There's about ten more minutes of discussion of 'The Four Agreements' and other self-help books, many of which are terrific. There's no shame in seeking help is my point. Anyway, it's all in the transcript. The upshot is we're looking for two DBs at some sort of air strip, one or both possible military. I guarantee you one of them is our Bigfoot here. Loach holds up a blow-up of the lipstick cam still. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 711 712 713 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 10.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The cops get up, start to file out past Moss, who's looki at Barry's photo on the board. She takes it down, exits. INT. THEATER, WORKSPACE — DAY (D12) 712 Barry enters from the backdoor, spots himself in the mirr Jesus, he looks like hell. Sally passes by in the hallway, spots him, descends like heat-seeking missile.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Barry, where have you been? Jesus, you look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, I just --

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: The cops came and found money hidden in the theater, and they shot a guy. They think Ryan was involved with the mob.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Also, we changed the scene, I'm Macbeth and your line is different. Sally turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally on stage, running the scene. She utterly sucks.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: I have almost forgot the taste of fears The time has been my senses would have cooled -- Wooden. Stiff. Self-conscious. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 713 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: IN THE WING: Barry arrives, watches her perform for a bea when -- BACKSTAGE: Natalie and Sasha walk through toward the dressing area.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: There's no way that was Ryan's money. He borrowed money from me, like, fifteen times.

dialogues.speaker: SASHA
dialogues.text: And if he had all that cash, why didn't he take new headshots?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. Hello. His still have bangs. ONSTAGE: Sally continues to struggle.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: To hear a night-shriek, and my fell of hair Would at a dismal treatise rouse and stir As life were in ’t. Then, she breaks character.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Gene, I could really use some direction here? Any thoughts? COUSINEAU, slumped in his seat, looks like he slept in hi car, still reeling from his break-up with Moss.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: I think...to use a technical term, it sucks. Maybe we go back to Lady MacBeth? Chalk all this up to an overreach?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: No. I'm playing MacBeth.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: You sure? Barry can scream his one line in either scene. IN THE WING: Barry's phone rings, he checks his phone, ro his eyes, answers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Chris, man, you gotta stop calling me.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you, man.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: You need to chill the fuck out. ONSTAGE: Sally resumes.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I have supped full with horrors. Direness, familiar to my slaughterous thoughts! Cannot once start me. She glances to the wing. This is Barry's entrance. Where fuck is he? ANGLE: Barry's still on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Chris, calm the fuck down, dude. ONSTAGE: Sally repeats:

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: -- Cannot once start me!

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Fuck. I'll call you back. Finally Barry stumbles out, a complete mess.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (AS SEYTON)
dialogues.text: (yells) My Queen, My Lord, the Lord is dead.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That's not...I can't. I just can't. She heads off.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: Let's take a tight five people. Tight five.  714 715 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry slumps into a seat. Cousineau pipes up from his sea nearby.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: That was something. You charged out there, equal parts loud and wrong. Eyes like saucers. Blood in your hair. Barry feels his hair. It may actually be Ponch's blood. Cousineau grabs a chair, flips it around and sits facing Barry. COUSINEAU (cont'd) It's drugs, isn't it Barry? Look, getting clean is an important part of the actor's journey. Quick story to illustrate: I was doing Long Day's Journey Into Night at the Pasadena Playhouse with a bunch of cokeheads. It's normally a three hour show, but we could bring it in in just under thirty-seven minutes. We felt great, but apparently it was completely unintelligible. It was the beginning of the bad years, Barry. I felt --

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I'm not on drugs, Mister Cousineau.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, that's not good news. Because it's one line, Barry. Cousineau puts his chair back where he found it. COUSINEAU (cont'd) And tonight, if you're not high, and you still can't successfully deliver one line? Well, I'm afraid this may not be for you. Cousineau saunters off leaving Barry alone in the theater Barry's phone buzzes again. Chris is calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moss is on her computer. She's on FACEBOOK, searching for "Barry Berkman" but there's no hits. That's odd. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 715 716 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 14.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Loach approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LOACH
dialogues.text: Hey. Lancaster's Sheriff's got a shot up car near an air strip - two DBs - both Marines.

dialogues.speaker: MOSS
dialogues.text: (cocky) Let me guess. (slams down Barry's picture) One of them is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: LOACH
dialogues.text: No. But if you'd been right, that would've been cool. INT. TAYLOR’S APARTMENT — DAY (D12) 716 Moss and Loach pass two uniform cops at the door and ente the apartment, in the process of a search. Two forensics guys, dressed much like the TID guys, wearing gloves. Two other detectives in raid jackets. A lieutenant. And a photographer are present as well. Moss and Loach eye Taylor's Marine Photo.

dialogues.speaker: LOACH
dialogues.text: His name's Taylor Garrett. Six foot. He's 415, a real hot head, and some 390s, drunk in public...broke a guy's jaw in a bar once... He gestures to a shrink-wrapped brick of money. It has a familiar appearance. LOACH (cont'd) Same brick as at the theater. Same exact amount. They split it. This guy and Ryan were working together.

dialogues.speaker: MOSS
dialogues.text: Slow down. We need to connect them to each other. Moss spots something on a nearby shelf. A familiar face staring back at her. She crosses to it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MOSS (cont'd) (to photographer) You shoot this already? The photographer nods. Moss pulls a glove out of her notebook, pulls it on, reaches for a book. It's Cousineau book. His face on the cover smiles back at her. Moss opens the cover page. Written inside, in cursive crayon: Ryan Madison. Moss motions to the photographer, ‘ a shot of this.' Loach looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LOACH
dialogues.text: I'd say that's a connection, wouldn't you? Say it. Say it... Finally --

dialogues.speaker: MOSS
dialogues.text: This is our guy. This is our Bigfoot. She looks down at Cousineau's smiling face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtains drawn. Fuches sits in a chair next to a half bot of whiskey, his phone in his hand, talking in an emotiona voice.

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: He couldn't've been more than five when I saw his dumb face the first time. Sweetest kid you ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank's got his seat all the way back, whispering into his phone.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: You know how sometimes when you meet a person you can tell exactly what they looked like when they were a kid? That's how I feel about my Barry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 718 719 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 16.

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. It's a child's eyes looking back at you. It's why he needed me so much.

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: I went to the store this morning. And I saw a man there and just for one second I thought, "Barry?" But it wasn't him. It was not Barry.

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: You know...he never got a chance to apologize to me. And now...it's too late. (then) So, where are we after all this? Are we okay?

dialogues.speaker: NOHO HANK
dialogues.text: Well, to be honest, Goran is very upset you told him to start war with Bolivians, who are super nice guys. So no matter where you go, we will find you and kill you. But not before we get ducks in a row with Bolivians, so maybe a week or two? Is that okay? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: FUCHES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car parked in an isolated turnout deep in the canyons north of the valley. It's quiet. An occasional car whizze by on the highway in the distance. Chris is in the driver's seat. Barry, the passenger.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Dude, Taylor and Vaughan...they're dead. Fuckin' dead.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Relax.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We just left their bodies out there. What...what do I do next time I see Vaughan's girlfriend. What do I say? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Say you don't know anything. We just gotta lay low, man. And keep quiet about all this.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I fuckin' killed a guy. I...I wasn't in the shit, man, I was in logistics. I never shot anyone.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: You had to do it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I can't stop thinking about it. It just plays in my head over and over. I didn't even want to do it. You made me do it.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Chris. You need to relax, man. You hear me? Relax. Don't say anything to anyone, and this will all blow over. Chris stews for a moment. He can't relax.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Listen: I think we need to go to the cops.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We can say it was self-defense -- that they attacked us. Who are they gonna believe? We're fucking Marines -- they're criminals!

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Chris...what do you think we were doing out there? What do you think I do for a living? (beat) The guys who hired me to do that job are already pissed I fucked it up. They sent a dude after me. We need to --

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I can't live like this! We could go to jail. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beat. BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 18.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: The only way anyone is going to jail is if you call the police. And these guys I work for will come find your family. Understand what I'm saying? We're good. We're just gonna stay quiet and safe.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What if I just turn myself in? I wouldn't have to say anything about you --

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: We're linked, Chris.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Nothing about you --

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: We're linked on Facebook. Your wife met me. If you turn yourself in, the cops are gonna find me.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, they wouldn't, they wouldn't have to --

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: They would, they'd find out about me and Fuches, and the acting class - everyone would die. Chris explodes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I don't fucking care, Barry! I killed a guy. You might be fine with this shit, but I'm not. I got a wife and a kid. The minute I got home, she knew something was up. I lied and said I was going to the gym just now. But, I'm telling ya, she knows something is up and it's gonna come out. So, I'm going to the cops and I'm telling the truth. If I have to serve some time, fine, but I'm coming clean.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Why did you just say that? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Can't believe you Facebooked me, dude. You're a fucking hitman and you Facebook me?!

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Why did you say that? A beat. Barry stares at Chris. BARRY (cont'd) I_told you to get out of the fucking car! ON CHRIS. He feels something. A shift in the energy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Y'know what? It's fine. I can keep it quiet. I just needed to vent. But, I'm good. I can keep quiet. Barry says nothing. CHRIS (cont'd) And, I didn't tell my wife I was going to the gym. I said I was coming to see you. Barry says nothing. Just then, another car pulls off to the side of the road hundred yards away. A DUDE gets out, ties down the stuff the roof-rack extra tight. Barry and Chris watch. Here’s Chris’ chance. Is he gonna flag the dude down? CHRIS (cont'd) I know you're not gonna do anything crazy, Barry. I know you're a good guy. The dude gets back in his car, drives off.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: I'm going to drop you off, and I'll go home and keep my fat trap shut. Chris starts the car. ON BARRY --

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: And I promise you, no one will ever -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 719 720 721 722 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chris has both hands on the wheel now. Barry claps a hand Chris's right hand and pins it to the wheel, pulls out hi Glock and as Chris flails with his free hand -- BANG -- Barry shoots Chris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Barry's voice, from inside the car, a terrible scream

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Fuuuuuuuuuck. We move in TIGHTER. Barry gets out of the running car. We PUSH PAST BARRY to see inside the car: Chris. His head slumped in death. The gun now clenched in his own right hand. The car door closes. Barry grabs a piece of brush, sweeps his tracks as he wal away, down the dark road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full house. A BUZZ in the air. The theater is packed. The performances are about to start. Cousineau can be seen ushering VIP Guests to their taped off reserved seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. The entire class is putting on costumes, applying make-up, working elaborate hair styles. Antonio and Natal are doing vocal exercises, bent over a chair, repeating:

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIO/NATALIE
dialogues.text: Many men making much money. Many men making much money. Many men making much money -- Cousineau comes flying backstage.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: Everyone! Bring it in. Jermaine, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (AS PUCK)
dialogues.text: Who be this Nick of whom you speak? A nick, a scratch upon this skin that doth draw blood? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 722 723 724 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21.

dialogues.speaker: SASHA
dialogues.text: He's in character.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: We're doing that now, are we? Alright. Puck, take a knee. The actors surround him. COUSINEAU (cont'd) Two minutes to curtain, all! It'sa veritable Who's Who of Hollywood out there. The red-headed-reader from ICM, that no-one-knows-what-she-does from 3 Arts. Daniel Meldman from Gersh. Sally perks up.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: He came?

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: I wish you Godspeed. I wish you courage. And remember, whatever happens, loud, fast, and just keep going. He heads off. Everyone goes back to getting ready. Except Sally.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Has anyone seen Barry? INT. UBER — NIGHT (N12) 723 Barry in the backseat of an Uber. He looks like hell. He looks out the window in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gauzy idealized version of a performance. SALLY is cent stage in a male Elizabethan costume delivering Macbeth to the delight of the elegantly dressed crowd.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: I have supped full with horrors. Direness, familiar to my slaughterous thoughts, Cannot once start me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 724 725 726 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now, Barry enters to a soupcon of applause, which he both graciously accepts and modestly shrugs off. He is reminiscent of Sir Laurence Olivier, full British accent.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (AS SEYTON)
dialogues.text: The Queen, my Lord, is dead. There’s an audible GASP from the audience. Barry humbly exits. Sally brilliantly continues.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: She should have died hereafter. There would have been a time for such a word. She’s unreal. Barry beholds her from the wings, amazed an in love. And then -- SALLY (AS MACBETH) (cont'd) Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow, Creeps in this petty pace from day to day -- FLASH ON: Chris, flailing as Barry holds a gun to his hea FIRES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry starts. The daydream having turned to a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're with the audience as the lights are coming down. Cousineau starts clapping, trying to ignite a pre-show ro of applause. It goes nowhere. Lights up. Sasha enters and comes to center stage.

dialogues.speaker: SASHA
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome. Recently, our friend Ryan Madison was taken from us too soon. Because of this, all of the proceeds from tonight's show will go toward the fight against violence. She walks off as a few confused people clap. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 726 727 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The curtain opens. Jermaine (in tights holding a skull) dramatically takes stage, crosses to a mark, takes a brea then flubs his very first line.

dialogues.speaker: JERMAINE
dialogues.text: Alapse poor -- blub-alub. Uch. I'm gonna come in again. He walks off stage. Cousineau looks around. This is worse than he thought it would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally dashes up to Natalie and Antonio.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIO
dialogues.text: I'm just saying we really need to lean into the sexuality.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Oh, boy, I --

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Barry's not here, and I need someone to do his stupid part. Is there any way one of you guys could help me?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (fake Italian accent) Sorry. We no can'a do that. We have'a to keep our Italiano accents for our'a scene from Two Gentlemen from Verona.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIO
dialogues.text: (normal accent) She is exactly right. If we don't keep speaking in these accents, we will lose them.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It's one line.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (fake Italian) We have'a saying in'a Italy. You make'a you bed. She turns to Nick. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 727 728 729 730 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 24.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Nick, do you think you could please --

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nick? Never heard'eth of him. Nick blows past her.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Fuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The show continues. Eric and Sasha do a Chicago gangster version of Titus Andronicus. Natalie and Antonio perform something vaguely resembling Gentlemen from Verona. Antonio leans into the sexuality. Natalie retreats. The audience endures. Cousineau rides it out. Daniel Meld from Gersh gets a lot of texting done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry enters in a daze. A frantic Sally spots him.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You're here. And you're not in costume. Well...fuck it. We're up! Put this on. It's something. She grabs a Hamilton-style jacket from a rack, thrusts it Barry, who starts to put it on over his street clothes. SALLY (cont'd) Come on! It's places. Now. She pushes Barry into the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick's on stage doing Puck. Sally and Barry in the wings.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: (sotto, nervous) My Lord, the queen is dead. My Lord, the queen is dead. My Lord, the queen is dead -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 730 731 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 25.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Barry, look at me. Here's what's happening. You see that guy out there on his phone? ANGLE: A guy in the audience doing a bad job of pretendin not to be on his phone. SALLY (cont'd) That's Daniel Meldman from Gersh. He was Emma Stone's agent until she got too big for him and fired him. He's here to see me. But if I don't do well, it's over for me. He'll never sign me. I'll never get him to work for me. And I'll certainly never get to fire him. So please, please, please give me something to work with. Can you do that? Barry's in a fog.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Fuck. Just...whatever. The lights go down on stage. A smattering of applause. Sa takes a deep breath. Nick walks off past Sally.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, Puck just took a big dump out there. That guy sucks... Sally heads on stage leaving Barry alone in the wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's entirely dark. We hear, but can't really see, Sally frantically take her place center stage. a buzz of lights they come up.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: I have almost forgot the taste of fears. The time has been my senses would have cooled -- ANGLE: COUSINEAU. Slumping down in his seat. She stinks.  732 733 734 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry, hands over his face, trying to concentrate, keep himself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH ON: A FAMILY PHOTO of Chris, his wife, SHARON, thei kid. FLASH ON: SHARON'S KITCHEN - Sharon enters frame, answers phone. BACK TO: Barry tries to shake it off. FLASH: Sharon gets the bad news. Her features collapse. H heart races. She cries. BACK TO: Barry once again tries to shake it off. FLASH ON: Chris' son cries. Sharon tries to hug him, to comfort him. BACK TO: Barry hits himself, trying to make it stop. FLASH ON: Mother and son cry over a casket. BACK TO: Barry hits himself again, harder. FLASH ON: Sharon answers the phone. FLASH ON: Sharon drops the phone, slumps to the floor, crying. BACK TO: Barry hits his head on the wall. And then WE HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: -- cannot once start me. Barry's cue. He turns, stumbles out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry has entered. Sally, expecting the stiff, wooden idi she's been rehearsing with, turns to see: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 734 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Barry, crying. Real tears of wrenching grief. Frustration Desperation. Through this squall, with monumental effort, bravely speaks:

dialogues.speaker: BARRY, (AS SEYTON)
dialogues.text: My lord, the queen, is dead. And then he just weeps. All the emotion spills out. The self-loathing, the regret, the guilt, the shame. Barry so as he stumbles blindly off the stage. The crowd is stunned and confused. But Sally? She thinks all his emotion was summoned FOR HER. She abso it, revels in it - is utterly invigorated by it. His catharsis is fuel to her own sputtered emotional flame. S turns back to the audience with new confidence:

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: She should have died hereafter. There would have been a time for such a word. Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow, Creeps in this petty pace from day to day -- ANGLE: PUSH IN ON THE AUDIENCE. Daniel from Gersh actually starts looking up from his pho The red-headed reader from ICM, what's-her-face from 3 Ar they're all engaged.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: To the last syllable of recorded time, And all our yesterdays have lighted fools. A small smile comes to Cousineau's lips.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: (low) Atta girl. Back ON SALLY: as she AMPS UP for the big finish.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (AS MACBETH)
dialogues.text: The way to dusty death. Out, out, brief candle! Life’s but a walking shadow, a poor player That struts and frets his hour upon the stage (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 734 735 736 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SALLY (AS MACBETH) (cont'd) And then is heard no more. It is a tale Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, Signifying nothing. She's amazing. Cousineau leaps to his feet, clapping. The crowd politely applauds with him. If nothing else, she's gotten their attention. Daniel fro Gersh makes a face, "not bad." The lights go down. Sally beams in the darkness. Then, lights up, and the rest of the cast come out for the curt call. Sally looks around, no Barry. She looks to the wings for Barry, he's not there. INT. THEATER, WORKSPACE — MOMENTS LATER (N12) 735 Barry paces like a caged animal, still manic, crying. He tears off the Hamilton jacket. When suddenly we hear: CLAP. CLAP. CLAP. Barry looks up. Cousineau is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: COUSINEAU
dialogues.text: Bravo. You went to a place just now that I have never seen you go. So, bravo to you for -- Barry punches the framed photo of Cousineau and Judd Hirs COUSINEAU (cont'd) I see that you're still in that place. I'll leave you to your process. I have a couple of small notes on the scene. But, that's for later. As Barry continues to reel, Cousineau backs out of the ro INT. THEATER, BACKSTAGE — LATER (N12) 736 The backstage area which is now crowded with jubilant actors, some of their friends and family, bouquets of flowers, etc. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 736 737 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 29.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Barry emerges in a daze. As he heads toward the exit tryi not to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The houselights are up. A smattering of people remain. Barry comes out from backstage, heading for the aisle and the exit. Barry looks up to see Sally shaking Daniel from Gersh's hand. As he heads out Sally turns and spots Barry.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Hey, Barry! She runs up. SALLY (cont'd) Look! She holds up Daniel's business card. SALLY (cont'd) Daniel. From Gersh. He told me to call him. He said there was a lot to work with there.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: Oh. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Barry. Thank you. For doing that for me. That was...amazing. I didn't even have to act. You just gave it to me. Everything I needed. God, you were so generous. That was acting, Barry. You're a real actor.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yes. Whatever you did to get to that place today, that is your new process. All you have to do is do that, every time, okay? I'm going to go change. We're all going out for drinks! Thanks, Barry! She gives him a kiss, runs backstage. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 737 BARRY - 107 - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hold on Barry as he looks around the theater. WIDE SHOT of Barry standing alone on the stage. Do that again? CUT TO BLACK.
